The Dawes prism is an isosceles right-angle prism with a refractive index of \( n = \sqrt{2} \).

The refractive index of the Dawes prism is \( n = \sqrt{2} \), the light ray is parallel to the base \( CD \) and enters through edge \( AC \), and the angles at \( A \) and \( B \) are both \( 45^\circ \).
Since the prism is an isosceles right-angle prism, the angles at the base are \( 45^\circ \). This means the angles between the edges and the base are also \( 45^\circ \).
The light ray is parallel to the base \( CD \), so the angle of incidence \( \theta_i \) is equal to the angle of reflection \( \theta_r \).
Using the properties of the Dawes prism, the refractive index \( n = \sqrt{2} \) implies that the angle of incidence is \( 45^\circ \).
Since the refractive index \( n = \sqrt{2} \), the angle of refraction \( \theta_r \) is also \( 45^\circ \).
Since the light ray is parallel to the base \( CD \), the light can exit from edge \( CD \) because the angle of incidence equals the angle of refraction.
The light can exit from edge CD.
